newsitem.title: INDIA: Security cordon thrown around Kashmir assembly.
newsitem.headline: Security cordon thrown around Kashmir assembly.

text.p: The legislature in India's Jammu and Kashmir state convened on Friday for the first time since the eruption of a violent separatist rebellion in 1990.
Police and paramilitary troopers sealed off a large area around the assembly building in the state's summer capital Srinagar, where lawmakers gathered after their election in local polls last month.
A paramilitary trooper and two civilians were injured when suspected separatist guerrillas lobbed a grenade at a security picket, 150 metres (yards) from the assembly building, police said.
Except for police and security petrols, streets around the assembly building were deserted on Friday.
Paramilitary troops could be seen on the roofs of residential buildings next to the assembly building, which overlooks the Jehlum river.
More than 20,000 people have died since the separatist revolt broke out in 1990, police and hospital officials say.
After two aborted attempts in 1995, Indian authorities organised assembly elections last month which were marked by sporadic violence.
"The ballot has already won a remarkable victory. The bullet must now make its exit," governor K.V. Krishna Rao told the assembly.
The legislative assembly had not met since September 1989. After the separatist insurgency erupted in early 1990, New Delhi imposed direct federal rule over the Himalayan region.
The new chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, has an absolute majority in the recently elected 87-member assembly.
He has pledged to win greater autonomy for the state and offered to hold peace talks with separatist leaders, who have rejected the gesture.
